intro: Bactris charnleyae, commonly known as the Charnley's palm, is a rare and unique species native to the Andean region of South America. It is a member of the Arecaceae family and is characterized by its slender, clustered stems and pinnate leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are typically followed by edible, fibrous fruits. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a threatened species. Its botanical features make it an important subject for conservation and botanical research.
